Establishing design space

Bounding Boxes

This module defines the bounding box surrounding the polyhedral design space, it has many classes for the variety of box-types that the bounding_box can presume.

class mango.design_spaces.bounding_box.CubicBox(a: float)[source]

Bases: object

This is a bounding box exhibiting Isometric (Cubic) Conditions by default. All edges are held to the same length and all angles are held to 90 degrees.

Parameters

a : Magnitude of all parallelepiped edges

a: float
return_box_traces(text_size: float) → tuple[source]

This function returns traces displaying the a b c and alpha beta gamma values via plotly

Parameters:

text_size – Desired font size in units of pt

Returns:

Various traces that are assigned to a plotly figure

update_shape()[source]

Function that simple updated the shape and bounding_graphs based on the updated values

class mango.design_spaces.bounding_box.HexagonalBox(a: float, c: float)[source]

Bases: object

This is a bounding box exhibiting Hexagonal Conditions by default. Here the edges in X and Y are held the same and a value of the height is specified. Further, the angles alpha and beta are held to 60 whereas gamma is 120.

Parameters

a : Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in x, y c: Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in z

a: float
c: float
return_box_traces(text_size: float) → tuple[source]

This function returns traces displaying the a b c and alpha beta gamma values via plotly

Parameters:

text_size – Desired font size in units of pt

Returns:

Various traces that are assigned to a plotly figure

update_shape()[source]

Function that simple updated the shape and bounding_graphs based on the updated values

class mango.design_spaces.bounding_box.MonoclinicBox(a: float, b: float, c: float, beta: float)[source]

Bases: object

This is a bounding box exhibiting Monoclinic Conditions by default. It’s edge lengths can be different along with an angle specified between c and a, but alpha and gamma are held to 90 degrees by default

Parameters

a : Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in x b : Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in y c: Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in z beta : Angle of parallelepiped between c and a

a: float
b: float
beta: float
c: float
edges_unique() → bool[source]

Validates if any one edge is the same value

return_box_traces(text_size: float) → tuple[source]

This function returns traces displaying the a b c and alpha beta gamma values via plotly

Parameters:

text_size – Desired font size in units of pt

Returns:

Various traces that are assigned to a plotly figure

update_shape()[source]

Function that simple updated the shape and bounding_graphs based on the updated values

class mango.design_spaces.bounding_box.OrthorhombicBox(a: float, b: float, c: float)[source]

Bases: object

This is a bounding box exhibiting Orthorhombic Conditions by default. It’s edge lengths can be different but the defining angles of the box are all held perpendicular (90 degrees).

Parameters

a : Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in x b : Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in y c: Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in z

a: float
b: float
c: float
edges_unique() → bool[source]
return_box_traces(text_size: float) → tuple[source]

This function returns traces displaying the a b c and alpha beta gamma values via plotly

Parameters:

text_size – Desired font size in units of pt

Returns:

Various traces that are assigned to a plotly figure

Function that simple updated the shape and bounding_graphs based on the updated values

class mango.design_spaces.bounding_box.Parallelepiped(a: float, b: float, c: float, alpha: float, beta: float, gamma: float, cell_type: str, angles_in_degrees: bool = True)[source]

Bases: object

This is a high level class that is used to initialize the various default conditions.

Parameters

a : Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in x b : Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in y c: Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in z alpha : Angle of parallelepiped between b and c beta : Angle of parallelepiped between c and a gamma: Angle of parallelepiped between b and a cell_type : What system is being shown (used in calculating volume) angles_in_degrees : Default TRUE, If false: will presume alpha beta gamma are in radians

a: float
alpha: float
angles_in_degrees: bool = True
b: float
beta: float
c: float
calculate_vertices_and_edges() → list[source]

How all the vertices are manually calculated

Returns:

List of all vertices defining the 8 corners of the parallelepiped

cell_type: str
edge_intersecting_box(point1: ndarray, point2: ndarray) → bool[source]

Determines if there is an intersection point between a line segment and a plane in the mesh.

Parameters:

  • point1 – Starting point of a line segment [X Y Z]

  • point2 – Ending point of a line segment [X Y Z]

:return True if an edge is intersecting a face, false if not

gamma: float
get_midpoint_of_each_face(vertices: list) → list[source]

This function will determine the mid-point of each face. We can then add grammars to “move” these face-based points if desired, for now we will hold this constant.

Parameters:

vertices – List of vertex node numbers we can access to pull correct values from graph

Returns:

List of midpoints in any face

static intersection_point(line_start: array, line_end: array, abcd: array) → bool[source]

Calculate the intersection point between a line segment and a plane if it exists.

Parameters:

  • line_start – Starting point of a line segment [X Y Z]

  • line_end – Ending point of a line segment [X Y Z]

  • abcd – Defining parameters of a face in Cartesian space

:return True if there is an intersection, False if not

update_face_equations() → None[source]

This function will calculate each face equation to use for comparisons and is called when a grammar is applied to extend the face directions, for example.

update_volume() → None[source]

Calculates and updates the volume attribute

class mango.design_spaces.bounding_box.RhombohedralBox(a: float, alpha: float)[source]

Bases: object

This is a bounding box exhibiting Rhombohedral Conditions by default. Here, all edges and angles are held to the same values, respectively.

Parameters

a : Magnitude of all parallelepiped edges alpha : Angle of parallelepiped between all edges

a: float
alpha: float
return_box_traces(text_size: float) → tuple[source]

text_size – Desired font size in units of pt

Returns:

Various traces that are assigned to a plotly figure

Function that simple updated the shape and bounding_graphs based on the updated values

class mango.design_spaces.bounding_box.TetragonalBox(a: float, c: float)[source]

Bases: object

This is a bounding box exhibiting Tetragonal Conditions by default. Here, a and b are held to the same value and c defines a height. All angles are held perpendicular

Parameters

a : Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in x, y c: Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in z

a: float
c: float
return_box_traces(text_size: float) → tuple[source]

This function returns traces displaying the a b c and alpha beta gamma values via plotly

Parameters:

text_size – Desired font size in units of pt

Returns:

Various traces that are assigned to a plotly figure

update_shape()[source]

Function that simple updated the shape and bounding_graphs based on the updated values

class mango.design_spaces.bounding_box.TriclinicBox(a: float, b: float, c: float, alpha: float, beta: float, gamma: float)[source]

Bases: object

This is a bounding box exhibiting Triclinic Conditions by default. It is the most “flexible” space as every parameter of the parallelepiped can be constrained.

Parameters

a : Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in x b : Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in y c: Magnitude of parallelepiped aligned in z alpha : Angle of parallelepiped between b and c beta : Angle of parallelepiped between c and a gamma: Angle of parallelepiped between b and a

a: float
alpha: float
angles_unique() → bool[source]

Validates if any one angle is the same value

b: float
beta: float
c: float
edges_unique() → bool[source]

Validates if any one edge is the same value

gamma: float
return_box_traces(text_size: float) → tuple[source]

This function returns traces displaying the a b c and alpha beta gamma values via plotly

Parameters:

text_size – Desired font size in units of pt

Returns:

Various traces that are assigned to a plotly figure

update_shape() → None[source]

Function that simple updated the shape and bounding_graphs based on the updated values of a, b, c

mango.design_spaces.bounding_box.create_parallelepiped(cell_type: str, a: float, b: float, c: float, alpha: float, beta: float, gamma: float)[source]

Design Spaces

This is the top level class responsible for maintaining the design features / qualities of a given design. This is effectively an environment from which we are applying grammars (actions) to.

class mango.design_spaces.polyhedral_design_space.PolyhedralSpace(bounding_box: TriclinicBox | MonoclinicBox | OrthorhombicBox | TetragonalBox | RhombohedralBox | HexagonalBox | CubicBox, preserved: list, excluded: list | None)[source]

Bases: object

This is a design space tasked with monitoring a polyhedral mesh for the export to automated design algorithms such as vHelix, DAEDALUS, and TALOS. This design space manages a 3D space via its design_graph

Parameters

bounding_box : BoundingBox data type, created preserved : List of PreservedVertex or PreservedEdge objects excluded: An optional list of Sphere or RectangularPrism objects

add_new_node(x: float, y: float, z: float, terminal: bool) → None[source]

This function will create a new node in our design graph

Parameters:

  • x – X position (nm)

  • y – Y Position (nm)

  • z – Z position (nm)

  • terminal – Is node terminal (i.e., a node that can NOT be removed) or not

Returns:

Nothing, modifies design_graph

bounding_box: TriclinicBox | MonoclinicBox | OrthorhombicBox | TetragonalBox | RhombohedralBox | HexagonalBox | CubicBox
calculate_input_parameters(edge_lengths: list, routing_algorithm: str) → dict[source]

This will return a standardized dictionary that will be used to allow for customized objective functions and design constraints, allowing for a more generalizable generative tool

Parameters:

  • edge_lengths – A list of all edge lengths in units of nm

  • routing_algorithm – Which algorithm is being used, options are currently: DAEDALUS and TALOS

Returns:

dictionary {property : value} where property is the key value

create_preserved_regions() → None[source]

This function will use the passed in preserved region spaces and specify these regions in the design_graph

Returns:

Nothing just updated the design_graph element

create_trimesh_mesh() → None[source]

This function is simply responsible for reconstructing a trimesh mesh file for the purpose of validating the mesh file. I deemed this “efficient enough” for the time being, but you could probably write some compiled code which does this much faster.

excluded: list | None
find_nonterminal_nodes() → None[source]

This function will find all of the non-terminal nodes in the design and append to a list that will be used to apply a variety of production rules to manipulate geometry.

Terminal nodes are those which belong to terminal geometries (preserved / excluded spaces). Nonterminal are all others

Returns:

Nothing, just appends to an ever-changing list of nonterminal nodes

generate_start_shape() → None[source]

This function adds all relevant edges on the initialized start_shape to the design_graph:

increment_node_count() → None[source]

Increments the node_count value by 1 so we can track the node values :return: Nothing, internally stored

jsonify_design_space() → dict[source]

This function will convert a design graph to a json-ified object such that I can plot it in the kodak visualization

preserved: list
static renumber_vertices(faces: array) → dict[source]

This function will take in the list of vertices and faces and re-number the faces to verify the index positions This is needed for writing out the .ply file to ensure proper file creation.

Returns:

Dictionary containing the mapping of old to new vertices values

triangulate_input_conditions() → tuple[source]

This function uses the alphashape to create a start shape for the generative process based on the input conditions defined by the designer. Future work may want to consider different types of triangulations, but the alphashape generalizes well to a concave or convex set of input conditions and therefore I use it here.

Returns:

A tuple of the faces of the triangulation and the related vertices of the mesh

validate_start_shape(shape: Trimesh | PolyData, preserved_edges: list, og_verts: ndarray) → tuple[source]

This function simply validates that the triangulated alphashape is able to be modified as expected by the application of various grammars

Parameters:

  • shape – Mesh element generated by alphashape algorithm

  • preserved_edges – A list of tuples that contain the nodes of any preserved edges.

  • og_verts – Original list of vertices from the preserved_regions

Returns:

(bool, list) : the bool returns if the shape is valid (true) or not (false) and the list contains the list returns a list of tuples defining the graph nodes of the preserved regions
